data.text:
@ZadkineAnn "We will never forget", says RTE, while shouting down anyone still affected by ongoing infection, lasting illness and the aftermath of loss with "We have reached a landmark moment... Covid-19 has ended".
https://t.co/br4nL3kNGV

@ZadkineAnn ^ My error. 1 in 36, not one third. There are some good comments and links about loss in this thread:
https://t.co/G0ldDnxion
@StuartDNeilson That's exactly what it feels like Stuart - Shut Up & Go Away

@ZadkineAnn I read one heart-rending account of the only person alive from a residential community of 90. His asked "why didn't God take me too?". I can't imagine the sense of bereavement among their carers & relatives. People need time & space to grieve. Ireland is saying "shut up".
@StuartDNeilson Thanks Stuart, yes it's huge & like whole generations are just disappearing, my mother was in a nursing home where 23 died, 70% had CV19 & many others 'unwell',

@ZadkineAnn People over 85 have lost one third of their peers, on average. Infectious disease is cruel. Some people live in residential and other communities where more than half of their friends have died. Irish society is even more cruel in this haste to forget Covid & the people affected.

@dazult_pdempsey We may have similar death rates, if we count deaths that would not have occurred in the absence of Covid-19 infection. These people would be alive now if not for Covid-19.
https://t.co/tvx0zVqZL7
@StuartDNeilson Even on the so called Day of Remembrance in March the dead are hardly being recognised https://t.co/X1Oq5bdVb6
